title: (x) Curvy magazine font - ITC Bookman Swash {Ben Archer}
content:
Hi guys,

I need help identifing the curvy magazine font.

Im also in the process of creating a print portfolio and looking to do a treatment on my name Chris. Can anyone recommend contemporary sans or san serif fonts with ligatures. In particular ligatures with letters in my name (ch, ri, is)

Thanks heaps!

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [curvy.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20061116104600/http:/typophile.com/files/curvy.gif) | 5.15 KB |
author: cjovanov

comments.content: Not so much ligatures as swashes, Chris; I think this is the old [ITC Bookman Swash,](http://web.archive.org/web/20061116104600/http:/www.itcfonts.com/fonts/font/pid/415684/ITC+Bookman+Swash+Volume/detail&grab_id=0&page_id=52015&query=%22bookman%22&SCOPE=ITCFonts) – at least the ‘r’ is, the cap ‘C’ may be handrawn. Others may have better recommendations…

[http://www.typography.net/type/aspect.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20061116104600/http:/www.typography.net/type/aspect.htm)

Has a few ch ligs you will have to adapt your own for the others though.

If you want a serif Esta has a couple of ch ligs as well

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/dstype/esta/ligatures/](http://web.archive.org/web/20061116104600/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/dstype/esta/ligatures/)

Tim

Without looking (sorry, no time), I’d bet that fonts designed by Spanish/Latin American designers would have interesting ch ligatures, since ch is a single character in Spanish.

Maybe something from Sudtipos?  
 [http://www.sudtipos.com/fonts2.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20061116104600/http:/www.sudtipos.com/fonts2.htm)

There was a “Type Battle” here several months back where lots of ligatures were created. This may be of some help in gettingideas. Try searching for the thread here.

ChrisL
